key_insight: Neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion can accurately generate and predict single-cell dynamic trajectories, enabling realistic in-silico perturbation studies of development and disease.
problem_solved: Captures complex, stochastic, state-dependent cell dynamics from single-cell data—overcoming limitations of deterministic or fixed-noise models that fail to represent cellular heterogeneity and realistic temporal variability.
method: Parameterize drift and diffusion terms of a stochastic differential equation with neural networks to model state-dependent dynamics and noise.
Train the generative neural-SDE on single-cell measurements to reproduce observed trajectory distributions and quantify uncertainty.
Use the learned model to simulate counterfactual perturbations and compare dynamics under different interventions.
impact: Demonstrates that neural SDEs provide a powerful, uncertainty-aware generative framework for biological time-series, enabling ML practitioners to build more realistic simulators and perform in-silico intervention studies for hypothesis testing and downstream tasks.
visual_elements: Phase-space plot showing observed single-cell trajectories overlaid with model-generated trajectories
Vector field visualization of learned drift and heatmap/ellipses showing state-dependent diffusion magnitude
Before/after simulations illustrating an in-silico perturbation (counterfactual trajectories)
Simple model diagram: data input → neural networks for drift & diffusion → stochastic integrator → generated trajectories
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
